PAAG,
PAN AMERICAN AIRWAYS COMPANY
GENERAL POST OFFICE BUILDING, THIRD FLOOR
250 NORTH SOOCHOW ROAD
SHANGHAI
Person
rson
Baguio, P. I.
Sept. 6,
1937
Mr. S. W. Morgan,
Pan
American Airways,
New York.
Dear Stokeley:
I was so wrong in my predictions as to the present Sino-
Japanese trouble that I feel in self defense an explanation is in
order.
I do not believe that any well informed parties in Shanghi
really anticipated war on any such scale as that at present going
on â€¢
The
actual circumstances to express it in another way,
were
somewhat
"Morgan
as though Jack Dempsey walked into your office
get under the desk"
You would first look around for help
and seeing no one,
desk.
if you had good sense you would get under the
If Dempsey
then proceeded to kick you in the pants you woud
then probably suffer that humiliation as gracefully as possible.
If he then came around and spit in your
face you might or might not
take it but if indignities were carried far enough you might then
come out from under the desk and sook him if you knew it were the
last act of your life.
That I believe is about the situation.
The
Chinese,
who are
extremely proud, suffered every
humiliation
at the hands of the Japanese until finally they could stand no
more and I personally do not believe that any of the responsible
Chinese
leaders at any time dared hope for victory.
I personally thought that Chiang Kai-shek would trade it
out with the Japs,
agree to a "show" in North China which would
and his own military an opportunity to
be pretty well agreed upon before the fight began
and would probably
involve recognition of the Japanese sphere of influence in North
China as well as other concessions.
This program I em quite sure
was under consideration when the Chire se patience became
exhausted,
and they decided instead to come out from under the desk.
Very sincerely,
HMB : MF
H. M. Bixby
